awd_titl_txt: NSF Student and Early-Career Faculty Travel Grant for IEEE International Conference on Software Engineering 2019 (ICSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funds for students and junior faculty to travel to the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 2019), which takes place in Montreal, Canada in May of 2019. ICSE is the flagship conference in the field. The conference is a venue for technical presentations of research results, interactions between academia and industry, and international collaborations. The specific objective of the grant is to increase and broaden participation in mentoring programs such as the Doctoral Symposium, the New Faculty Symposium, and the Student Mentoring Workshop.  The objective is to provide education, training and mentoring and to nurture a globally-aware workforce of research and educators within the US and build the community of researchers in the field of Software Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The overriding goal of the NSF ICSE 2019 Travel Award Program was to further the research directions and careers of diverse students and junior faculty members in software engineering at US-based colleges and universities. Toward this end, the project supported them to attend the premier research conference in the field of software engineering, the 41st International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 2019); participate in ICSE 2019’s mentoring, networking, and professional development programs (Student Mentoring Workshop, Doctoral Symposium, and New Faculty Symposium); and attend one or more ICSE 2019 workshops and co-located events, which serve as incubators for scientific communities that form and share a particular research agenda.

 

15 travel award offers were made to participants of the Student Mentoring workshop. Additionally, 3 awards were made for the doctoral symposium and 3 for the new faculty symposium. 

 

The awards allowed participants to leverage multiple opportunities to advance their careers at ICSE, including (a) attend and/or present their work in one of the ICSE 2019 main conference tracks, (b) attend the student mentoring workshop to de-mystify the graduate school experience, (c) attend and present a research proposal at the Doctoral Symposium, (d) attend the New Faculty Symposium, and (e) facilitate awardees to network with their peers and leading experts in their research areas.

 

The awards advanced professional development of students and faculty members, many from groups that are underrepresented in the field. The awards strengthen the field by introducing diversity of ideas and problem solving strategies. As the careers of these individuals advance, the field gains more diverse role models for others to emulate, thereby amplifying this effect. 


Last Modified: 12/01/2020
Modified by: Christian Kastner
